I always think of this game as one of my go-to games if I just feel like having some quick fun, mainly thanks to its Zombies mode.

Zombies is really the most remarkable out of all modes in this game for me.
From the custom maps to the 14 maps that you get by owning all DLCs, the mode is rich with content! You get 8 remastered maps from older games, all of which are all really great remasters, and also 6 base maps which are all mostly top-notch (Excluding Revelations, which is a bit duller in comparison, but still very good).

The multiplayer is really decent at best, the micro-transactions really do ruin the gameplay a bit; a ton of weapons that you can only unlock from supply drops and a system which just encourages you to spend money. Apart from that, though, the multiplayer is good fun. It doesn't really compare to the likes of Black Ops 2 but it  can still be enjoyed, especially thanks to the specialists which I actually liked.

The campaign shouldn't be something to get too excited about, to say the least. It's an absolute mess, they completely strayed away from the story in previous BO games and it just turned out horribly, characters are forgettable and the story is confusing.

Overall, I highly recommend this game to CoD Zombies fans mainly, as it is simply remarkable in this game. Others would probably still have a good time playing MP but you're really much better off playing the BO2 MP or something similar.

This version really feels like the most refined classic zombies experience so far. It may not be as "pure", but it is still very much the classic formula, just with some newer elements.
You have old maps ported to ùòâùò≠ùò¢ùò§ùò¨ ùòñùò±ùò¥ ùòêùòêùòê in the Zombies Chronicles DLC, any map you can dream up through Steam Workshop, and an overall modern refinement of the "classic zombies" formula.

The campaign is frustrating to me. It has several individual moments with awesome ideas or cool concepts, but none of it ends up amounting to anything. The whole campaign essentially ends up meaningless (no spoiler). There are quite a few neat ideas, like walking through virtual recreations of memories, but those same ideas have so many oversights that ruin it. Quite a few ideas fall flat and do not work, despite the presence of some ideas with great potential.

Multiplayer is also uninspired. It feels like the devs took a look at Titanfall and did the bare minimum to capture some of the magic of that game's movement system. The only problem is that it barely works and feels out of place. The weird "hero" abilities also do not feel like they fit. It is almost like they made the "Call of Overwatch" instead of a unique title with its own identity. The multiplayer sincerely fails at carving out its path and feels like a mix of other popular games.

Not enough content but its a good game. I didn't enjoy the mechanics of the game and the wall running seemed a bit harder than expected. I had issues using the jump boost and sometimes the campaign would not load the right save. Speaking of the campaign, I personally found it was dull and it followed the shadow of Black Ops 2 which was disappointing but then again BO2 was one of the best COD experiences along with MW2. I was really disappointed when I got to the jet mission and found that you had no control of where you fly which was disgusting to see since there was a jet mission in BO2 that allowed you to do all the flying and shooting which was amazing. I wish they had more zombies maps that you don't need to pay for in order to play because it was annoying that you can't play an official zombies map with your friends other than the one they included. The only other option was to download some workshop mods that sometimes don't work. The weapons were really different and I didn't really enjoy any of the weapons other than the sniper category. I think that they should reduce the pricing for this game since its 5 years old in the time of writing this review. I would rate this 6/10 and I don't recommend you download this since its pretty dead now in 2020.

Black ops 3 is a very interesting game. For me, I will only be speaking about the zombies portion of the game. Multiplayer and Campaign I played little to none and majority of my time has been sunken into zombies. Bo3 received critical acclaim and criticism because of this iteration of zombies. Personally, I love it and I think it will be the pinnacle of gameplay and community hype for all of zombies. Map after map there were endless little things to do with amazing environments, weapons, and detail. For some, this game might turn you off due to to things like having to look up videos to do certain things EVERY game (soe pack, kt4 build+upgrade, soe sword) but to me, Its those things that I always love to come back too and do every game. Without keeping this review too long, for anyone slightly interested in cod zombies, this is the best version imo. For returning players, I feel it has classic gameplay with added variety with gums and wonder weapons. Not to mention there are some really amazing custom maps that the community has made that make the entry price well worth it. :)

Months and months go by, consuming my life. It took me 3 months to kill the ender dragon for the first time.

This review is on the multiplayer aspect as i care not for the story/single player.

Pros

-Incredible movement system. Very fun, lots to learn, Awesome to watch.
-Tight controlls as every CoD
-Matchmaking is fairly fast, low pings

Cons

-Matchmaking is latency based, not skill based. Low skill players will have a steep learning curve to start.
-Controller usage gives aim assist, which in some cases is a very unfair advantage.
-Cod Points: Micro transactions. Yes, this game has microtransactions even though you are paying full price.
-Random package loot system. Lots of cosmetic items and new weapons. All are locked behind a fully random system. Some players who have played since release are yet to get one.
        +Addendum: There is now guaranteed weapons and they are stepping up the package frequency with contracts.
                               To be honest kinda too little too late. We'll see what happens when it's fully implemented.
-DLC packs are EXTREMELY low content. Four maps and a zombie map. For ~15 bucks. 
-This game desires to latch on to your wallet and never let go.


Overall, good game but poor practices mean the entire CoD franchise is becoming a waste of time. Shame.

Update: Just came back after a while away, was tired of controller aim assist and cheaters being all i see. First match back: blatant cheater, not even hiding it. Do not waste your money on this game. I'd even say don't waste your money on this company.

I got this game for the Zombies mode, unfortunately I have been completely unable to get even get past the press enter to start menu before I crash.
I have tried just about everything I could find on the discussion pages, from users to the devs themselves, here is a list of what I have done.
-Verified the game files
-Tried Safe Mode
-Reinstalled the game
-Restarted my computer before launching it
-Tried both Windows 7 and Windows 8 compatibility mode multiple times
-Both put the game folder and the exe itself on my allow list
-Disabled my anti virus entirely 
-Done a Clean Boot multiple times
All the other things I could find on the Official troubleshooting guide that I haven't tried are fairly specific causes of issues (multiple monitor software, using a controller) don't apply to me.
Specs:
-RX 580 
-16GB RAM
-Ryzen 2600
-1 TB SSD

Generally speaking, I would only recommend purchasing this game if you intend to be playing zombies. The multiplayer was quite lackluster to begin with and it shows its age. The zombies is, in my opinion, currently the best Treyarch zombies experience that money can buy. The official maps (and chronicles) are great, and are definitely appealing. However, it is the price that is a major hurdle. It costs way too much for what it is. I would recommend waiting for a sale to pick up most of the DLCs or the game itself, over 100 bucks for all the zombies content is somewhat ludicrous and I really can't justify it. But if you can get it at a better value, then I would definitely recommend.

The campaign sucks and the multiplayer sucks, but the zombies alone makes this one of the best CODs out there. With all of the DLC, the game has 14 zombies maps, so you won't get bored any time soon. But on the Steam version we have Workshop support, so custom maps are back, and people are still making maps-- now you'll never get bored. I used to play on Xbox One, so coming to Steam and seeing all these custom maps was an exhilarating experience.

I still think $100 dollars for the game plus all the DLC is way too much for a five-year-old game, even $60 for the game plus ZC is too much, so I'd wait for a sale. But if I'm being honest, because of how mediocre the DLC maps are, and with all the custom maps out there, I'd just get the base game. It's worth it solely for the custom maps.

TL;DR: It's worth it for the Zombies alone.

Call of Duty: Black Ops III tells a remarkable story of betrayal within the pursuit of immortality. Through the fascinating technology of Direct Neural Interfacing, mankind finds itself at war with machines but also with itself. The conundrum of existence and purpose is represented throughout the campaign. In my last playthrough, I was extremely impressed with the visuals and abstract environments that I found myself in. At times, places and their implied meaning felt so surreal. The gameplay mechanics can be a bit overwhelming sometimes and some of the abilities can feel too overpowered. Despite all of that, this is a strong experience and one that still provided a fun challenge on higher difficulties. If you want to play a deep futuristic war story that explores technological progress and humanity's role in all of that, then this black operation will be greater than just a tale of finding identity. Game on.

Okay, but seriously: the Zombies in [i]Call of Duty: Black Ops ‚Ö¢[/i] is good, at least in a conceptual manner.[list]For example:[*]In Pack-a-Punching a weapon more than once, you receive what's called an Alternative Ammo Type (AAT for short), and this makes killing zombies a lot easier. (To make this more balanced, it only ‚Äúactivates‚Äù every so often‚Äîperhaps every 30 seconds or so.)
[*]The maps in this game have [u]a lot of detail and content[/u] in them; they're vast and expansive, while actually still having ‚Äústuff to do‚Äù in all the various nooks and crannies. (At time of writing, I've only done one Easter-Egg so far‚Äîthat EE being the Flytrap from [i]The Giant,[/i] which per step literally the same as on [i]Der Riese[/i] in previous games.)
[*][u]The maps are designed well,[/u] in terms of general layout: a fair amount of challenge, but not too terribly difficult. (It's not quite [i]casual-friendly[/i]‚Ä¶[spoiler]but neither is the price [strike]even with sale[/strike]‚Ä¶[/spoiler]but I feel as though the learning curve isn't absolutely [i]terrible[/i] for anyone who's serious about having fun with Zombies.)
[*]On that ‚Üë note about maps, this is the [u]first Treyarch-made game since [i]World at War[/i] to natively support mods.[/u] Still currently the [i]only[/i] one, actually. [*][b][u]#@$!ing [i]terrible[/i] sound design![/u][/b] I will hear the zombies at all times in [i]Black Ops ‚Ö°,[/i] [i]Black Ops ‚Äú‚Ö°‚Ö°,‚Äù[/i] [i]Black Ops ‚Ö†,[/i] [b]and even [i]World at War[/i][/b]‚Äîthey'll either be walking, or at least groaning‚Äîwhereas in [i]‚Ö¢,[/i] you have zombies [i]literally sneaking up on you [b]in full and absolute silence[/b][/i] half the time!!!

One of the more fun COD titles treyarch did an amazing job with this game i 100% recommend it although the player-base is getting smaller every year if you love cod zombies especially i highly recommend buying this over bo2 / bo1 the community is pretty decent some sweats lots of noobs its a very noob friendly game and if you aren't used to the jetpack system the game still is a lot of fun just running around w out it ! same goes for the zombie mode its very noob friendly with the added gobble-gum system aswell as lots of overpowered weapons with double / triple pack-a-punch adding different buffs to your weapon i have to say revelations and the remastered bo1 and waw maps are def the best part of buying the season pass or the version of the game that gives you those maps! other than that bo3 is actually the one cod with matchmaking where u can actually find games as long as your doing it at peak hours but sadly the game is dying hopefully w the modding community and MW2 BO3 REMASTERED Mod the game will start to get more light but that's all i have to say 10/10 would recommend if your friends own the game aswell it will only add to the experience

This game is worth it just for Zombies. Some would argue that BO3 has probably the best zombies experience out of any COD, especially with Zombies Chronicles. Never was big on the Multiplayer for this game though (it's alright I guess...), I HATED the campaign for this.

Black Ops 3 is something of a CoD anamoly. As a whole package, Black Ops 3 is absolutely stuffed with content, while some content may be better than others, it's still content that helps this game remain fresh. Not to mention that Black Ops 3 has many features that are unique to it.
Some being:
- 4-player Campaign Co-op
- Steam Mod Support
- Fully customizable campaign experience, vanity and gameplay elements
- Entirely separate game modes that enrich the experience (Nightmares, Dead Ops Arcade 2, Freerun)

Treyarch really wanted this CoD to be something and it clearly shows that. Multiplayer was probably the smoothest of the advanced movement CoDs and it was also pretty fun, having plenty of unlocks kept giving me reasons to come back and grind. Zombies was the absolute best in the series, releasing some of the best zombies maps of the Blundell era and then later adding the Zelinski golden age with Zombies Chronicles, that's not to mention the plethora of content available on the Steam Workshop.

My only major complaints about this game are the campaign making absolutely zero sense in any way (though the gameplay loop remains fun) and the multiplayer dlc maps going overboard with the whimsical settings (viking village, medieval magic castle, mortal kombat-esque island). Other than that, this is probably the best CoD available on Steam and a total reccomendation. Well worth the price tag.

I'm a fan of many CoDs both MW and BO, started at BO1.
This is my fav so far, hands down.
MP was very well designed.  
Maps were well designed, 3 lane greatness.  Movement system was great.
Most importantly, the game had character.  Wasn't bland, didn't feel like "just another CoD."

Final Ratings (2020):

Campaign- 2/10 - almost no connection to the previous entries in the series as well as bad gameplay and storytelling makes this one of the weakest in the franchises history. This game's campaign simply pales in comparison to BO1's and BO2's Campaign.

Multiplayer - 6/10 - Progression and gameplay is very good, however the fact that there are as many weapons locked behind supply drops as there are in the base game, as well as an almost dead multiplayer community prevents me from rating this any higher. 

Zombies - 10/10 - 14 maps, a compelling story, refined gameplay, a passionate and thriving community as well as endless hours of fun in custom zombies makes this the definitive experience for any zombies fan and anyone looking to get into zombies.

[table][tr][th]Genre[/th][td]First-person shooter[/td][/tr][tr][th]Campaign[/th][td]Yes[/td][/tr][tr][th]Game length[/th][td]9 - 11hours[/td][/tr][tr][th]Difficulty modes[/th][td]4[/td][/tr][tr][th]Wikipedia Page[/th][td][url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Call_of_Duty:_Black_Ops_III] Link [/url][/td][/tr]

[b][h1]Overview[/h1][/b]
This game is a first-person shooter mode that is great like the previous Call of Duty series.
It can be said that after 5 years from the release of the game, it still has its own online players, but! Less time it takes to find a game server that is not annoying.
The offline part of the game also has a relatively interesting short story, which we will discuss its strengths and weaknesses

 üü© [b]CAMPAIGN[/b]
So... you liked the story of Alex and David Mason? You liked the way those characters were built and the intense narrative? You want more of the soldiers you know and love? Lol, no, ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• you. Treyarch decides to throw all of that in the trash and start anew with a story that has absolutely no link to the previous Black Ops games. I'm gonna be 100% honest with you here, I didn't understand a single bit of Black Ops 3's tale that it's so desperately trying to deliver in an interesting way. Spoiler alert, it's not interesting at all. While the other games were engaging and had deep, beautifully constructed plots, BO3 is a story about... ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• if I know. You basically play as a custom character (don't expect any depth to the level of customization, it's about 3 faces and 2 caps and that's it) which loses his/her limbs in an operation that goes terribly wrong. Then you get on a mission to destroy...the...Illuminati or something. Honestly it's quite twisted. What I'm trying to say is that the campaign isn't in the last bit memorable. Not the characters, not your motives, not anything. It's just a big mess. That's probably why you see so many "Train go boom" memes and "Black Ops 3 ending explained" videos on Youtube. But the gameplay of the campaign in itself is alright. The new thing is that you have some new, enhanced abilities which are actually pretty fun to use.



  üü© [b]ZOMBIES[/b]
 This is the part where Black Ops 3 shines the most. This is, without any doubt the best CoD game for zombies mode. Yes you have the classic 4 dlc formula for unlocking the current zombies maps, but there's also a dlc called "Zombie Chronicles" which allows you to play better, remastered versions of almost all of the zombies maps in previous CoD games. That is just awesome. Besides the fact that, in the age of Steam Workshop, you have hundreds of user-submitted maps at your disposal, maps which are pretty damn good most of the time. Even if you don't buy any dlc, the user maps and Shadows of Evil (the zombies map you get by default) are still gonna ensure you have a blast if you buy this game only for this mode. My respect to Treyarch for this amazing, top-notch zombies experience.


  üü© [b]MULTIPLAYER[/b]
 While many people don't take this game seriously because of the new movement mechanics, I can tell you the multiplayer here is quite solid. Unlike other CoD games, here you have specialists you can use in multiplayer instead of random/perk specific character models. These specialist have some abilities which give you an edge against other players, for example a bow with explosive arrows, invisibility, traps with nano-bees that kill any enemy that steps in them (it sounds ridiculous, I know), or some portable seismic charges that insta-kill nearby enemies (it may sound overpowered but you mostly get 1 or max 2 kills with it because of the short range and the fact that sometimes you don't even get to use them since you have to jump to trigger them and the enemy can kill you in mid-air). The new movement system with sliding and thrusters which allow you to glide or jump higher is actually well-implemented and smooth. It can make for some interesting plays or can be very frustrating at times, depending on the situation. But overall, it's a nice experience.


üü• The Bad Side
         -horrible story
         -I did not see anything else personally

------------------------------------------------
üü© The Good Side
        
         +Zombie Chronicles DLC  is worth every single penny
         +Steam Workshop allows for countless hours of fun with zombies maps
         +modifications to the multiplayer are a nice change of pace

First off, two things.

1. Don't buy this game if you're looking to play multiplayer or the campaign. They're both garbage.
2. GET THIS GAME WHEN IT GOES ON SALE! It usually goes on sale for ~50% off every summer or winter sale.

Those two things out of the way, Call of Duty Black Ops III is in my opinion the best CoD zombies experience there is. 
8 classic maps (9, if you include The Giant) beautifully remastered, all fun as hell, with 5 original maps (4 of them are DLC) that are in my opinion the best part about this game. On top of all that, the modding community is amazing. There's so many quality maps, some that even match the quality of the official maps. 
There's something for everyone. New CoD Zombies players can hop on the easier, more casual, simpler maps, such as Nacht, The Giant, and Kino. Or, if you've played zombies before, you'll love the more complex maps like Gorod Krovi, Origins, and Shadows of Evil.

However, it does have some negatives I would like to comment on briefly.
1. The game can be buggy as all hell. Like holy shit. The easter egg on the final DLC map, Revelations, the second to last step is so buggy that it can fuck up your whole run. So you can waste 2 hours, unless you down yourself to unglitch it, and that only works once as far as I'm aware. Origins is also glitchy as well, as my friends and I were doing the easter egg and it glitched and we just wasted several hours.
2. The zombie AI can be absolutely ridiculous. I see people saying that this zombies game is very watered down in difficulty due to the inclusion of Gobblegum and the 3-hit down system instead of the 2-hit, but that is completely negated by the AI in this game in my opinion. You can get hit up to 3 times by one zombie in a second, which can down you if you don't have the Juggernog perk.

And with all that being said, I still say this is the best CoD zombies you can play. It took the crown from Black Ops 1 in my heart (which is insane I never thought that would happen because I love that game to death), and I highly recommend this game to anyone.

As a long time COD Zombies fan, I only feel good about reviewing the zombies side of the game, so here it goes. 

Black Ops 3 delivers an interesting Zombies experience with its season pass DLC alone. I describe it as interesting because it really wasn't the best set of maps in my opinion. They were awesome in their own ways but they didn't give off quite the same feel as the maps in the past 3 Treyarch games.
That being said, this is still an amazing buy for an ultimate Zombies fan... If you are willing to shell out about $150. If you can do that, then you can have a great Call of Duty Zombies experience. Between 4 season pass DLC maps, The Giant DLC, and the Zombie Chronicles DLC, you are getting every single map that has featured the original 4 characters.
It is true that you won't get your favorites like Call of the Dead, Mob of the Dead, Buried, or Tranzit (lol), but you will still be getting a lot of content.
To say a little bit about the remastered maps in Zombie Chronicles - They look absolutely amazing. Treyarch has gone all out to push the limits of the newer resources they have in order to make each map glow with beautiful new lighting and even some new sound effects. The maps are extremely detailed and feature even some new easter eggs to discover.

So who do I recommend this to most? People who are new/interested in getting into COD Zombies. It's a full bundle with a ton of maps and even though $150 sounds like a lot, it would cost a ton more to buy all of the COD Zombies games and their DLC. Of course if you're a long time Zombies fan you will really appreciate the effort put into the remasters in the DLC.

Overall I give the Zombies section of this game a 9/10.

[h1]!!! FOR THE ZOMBIES MODE ONLY !!! [/h1] 

 I only purchased Black Ops III for the zombies mode with [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/581450/Call_of_Duty_Black_Ops_III__Zombies_Chronicles/] Zombies Chronicles[/url] and only play it for zombies. There's 14 maps to choose from and a workshop open to the community with over hundreds of hours worth of content. Great for beginners to CoD Zombies with the unique Gobble Gum system and a slight health boost compared to the other games. Immense fun with friends and randoms, even by yourself, but not worth the full price with or without DLC included. [b] Do yourself a favor and pick up a copy during a sale! [/b]

 So... if it's a mostly good experience besides the price tag, why the negative review? Crashes, soft-locks, bugs and the classic 5-hit-in-1-frame zombie attack unfortunately hinder the game's potential. Some of the remastered maps from the Zombie Chronicles DLC, such as Origins, can be broken from doing something as simple as going to the wrong place on the map at the wrong time. For a game that can cost up to $80 it's unacceptable to run like its been put together with tape and bits of string. [b]Black Ops III Zombies is not unplayable but can be frustrating when things behind the curtains go haywire. [/b]

Let me update my review of this game's PC version. It is still one of the best PC versions of CoD  (Together with MW 2019) in this generation. I also liked the inclusion of the Split Screen mode where you can also do a trick to make split screen in 2 different monitors. Further optimization and modding support were implemented from time to time. A console version should be a must buy instead of the PC version, unless you're willing to play A BUNCH OF custom content and mods. The current gen consoles version is the best option to enjoy the optimized original content and multiplayer servers are full of ppl playing many different game modes. But if you want to have some fun with the custom content then there you have it. It's worth getting it during the sale.

Call of Duty black Ops 3 was my 1st call of duty game. It will always hold a special place in my heart. But this is a review so I have to be unbiased thus. I will look past my personal feelings and just look at the pure gameplay and feel of the game.

 Campaign wow what a shit show I cannot even begin to explain to you why this is a bad camping but I'll try.  OK for starters the story doesn't connect to the 1st 2nd game well enough which is already a bad sign. But that would be the least of our problems if that was the case and they made a good story it could be ignored but not only did it not connect to the previous games but it also had a bad story.  And I can't really explain the story to you because I don't know the story. It's bad that I have played this campaign 5 times. If I could go back and stop myself from playing this campaign I would but I played it for you so that I can write this review. After playing it 5 times I still can't write this review. The game play of the campaign missions was very linear. So over all a 2/10

 Now the multiplayer how does it hold up. Not that good to be honest the advanced movement kind of broke the Call of Duty formula that it established over the years and this is also around the era of loot boxes and heavy microtransactions I think that there are more DLC weapons then free weapons in this game. The maps are also 3 lane garbage And the leveling up system of the weapons doesn't feel extremely rewarding. Overall I give this multiplayer a 5/10

 Now how does this game handle Zombies? My God it is my favorite zombie out of all the Call of Duty games All the DLC maps are great.  Shadows of evil amazing map. der eisendrache arguably one of the best. Zetsubou no Shima is hated by most of the community But personally it's my favorite map of all time. gorod krovi Great map. Revelations good map for beginners really easy. Chronicles 8 remastered maps from the other games imported into the B03 engine. 3 from world at war. 4 from black Ops one. One from black Ops 2. And then you technically have the giant which is a world at war map but that's not Chronicles. Then there is custom zombies which opens up unlimited doors and upon purchase of the game you get the free mod tools to create your own maps. Overall I give a 10/10

Regarding the campaign:

1. The 'player's' body dies halfway thru the second mission, when your training with Taylor's squad.
2. From then on, the player is a DNI backup of your mind, living on in a simulation running (at first) in John Taylor's DNI / Brain, created by the CORVUS AI. CORVUS is the infection.   
3. In that simulation, each time you interface with one of Taylor's team via DNI, that member DIES in the real world. Sarah Hall is particularly confused when this happens, but realizes whats happening just before she dies. Each interface also spreads the infection, which has been incubating in the running simulation.
4. In the final mission, you play IN TAYLOR'S BODY in the real world, however the player grabs control of him. That's why Kane is confused when you say "You didn't leave me" or something.
5. Taylor guides the player into Coalessance HQ and tricks him into 'purging his DNI'. The player does this, not realizing he IS the infection at that point. 
6. The infection having been purged, Taylor, now back in control of his mind, greets the arriving troops. The voice sounds like the player because all thru the simulation, Jon Taylor wore the players face, and you wore Jon Taylors :)

After having reached over 1000 hours in this game and 1300 across other accounts, as well as completing 90% of the achievements, I can confidently say that this is my favorite game I have ever played. Between the fun times I've had with friends playing zombies, canonical or custom, and the exhilarating Mirror's-Edge-Simulator that is multiplayer, this experience offers fun-filled ingredients in a tightly wrapped tortilla.

[h1]Campaign[/h1]
The campaign will never be as good as the first two black ops campaigns, but it's not as bad as people have made it out to be. Albeit I had to do outside research to figure out what the heck was going on (especially the ending). If you are into getting all achievements, then go crazy; However, the missions didn't leave a lasting impact on me, so if not, then don't play it.
5/10

[h1]Multiplayer[/h1]
I personally love the multiplayer. It's dead except for soft-core TDM. But back when the game first came out, it  was on fire. Running into the same people was kind of cool and the dlc weapons were not only exciting but overpowered. The camos are incredibly beautiful, especially the dark matter camo.
My favorite part of this mode was the melee. The comical variety that the melee weapons offered, like slashing up people with a samurai sword, or backhanding people with a mannequin arm, the combo of parkour and smacking people around provided some great laughs and salty reactions to people getting killed.
[b]Beware:[/b] there are alot of fake level 1000s in lobbys due to bought accounts and some hackers here and there nowadays.
8/10

[h1]Zombies[/h1]
This mode is the only real reason to buy this game in 2020. This is the peak of zombies in my opinion. Each dlc map was innovative and exciting and never boring in it's own way, and revelations is one of my favorite all time maps.  The custom zombies maps are not to be slept upon either, some of which are just as good as the canonical maps.
10/10
10/10, simply delicious, paid $50 for the base game, zombie chronicles, and the season pass. totally worth it.

My main issue is I wish Money vision would just remove the normal version of this game and bundle all the dlc's with a new re-release "ultimate edition" for the same price, kinda lame having all the dlcs and not being able to actually play on them because no one has them or even has them off for faster match times

Great game. Multiplayer is for sure not the best but still gave me good memories. Campaign is awful however. Zombies on the other hand; I could never ask more in a COD zombies game. SOE is a great map for free, the paid for maps are 100% worth the value however this is not where the value in the zombies mode lies. Custom zombies is one of the most immersive zombies experiences that I could have ever asked for; there is no limit to the number of maps I can play so there are countless hours that I can spend in this game mode alone.

Hours of gameplay to enjoy. Multiplayer is similar to older games in the series, with some new mechanics, so it keeps it fresh. Zombies is bigger than ever, huge beautiful maps. but where the game really shines is through the workshop content. The sheer number of mods and maps that you can use are insane. they range from very mediocre WIP maps to full, feature length maps with easter eggs and custom weapons. More than worth checking out.

Campaign - Campaign is really not that good compared to older Black Ops games. I would say it has the worst campaign in Black Ops. 

Multiplayer - Multiplayer is really fun. My all time favourite. The guns are balanced (except for brecci and xmc) the movement is really fun with thruster jump. The specialists are not overpowered. This game has the best skins in all of COD games after and they are worth the grind. As a bonus, this game also has gold character skins but the grind for that will take you a good 200 hours. This game also has black market, where you open cases to get dlc guns and cosmetics, do challenges and unlock mercenery contracts. The maps are good. BO2 Nuketown is the best and this one comes after that in my oppinion. This game has 10 prestige levels going up to level 55 in each prestige. After prestige 10 you unlock prestige master going up to level 1000. 

Zombies - Zombies is extremely fun. The only downside is the games can last really really long (once went up to 102nd round and it took me 10 hours). All the maps are fun to play and my fav is ascension. I recommend zombies chronicles edition.

I have mostly positive things to say about Black Ops III. I surely do love BO3 to this day, and always will. I don't see as many hackers but people using controllers can be really annoying. I have been playing BO3 in the Middle East on European Servers and I would usually have a decent to terrible ping of 150-250 ms, where 150 ping is the best I have gotten. I believe Activision need to invest on dedicated servers in the Middle East/Asia because there are a majority of players in Asia that are forced to join EU servers and have their experience ruined from the terrible connection. As for the gameplay, I have little problems with the advanced movement in MP and the weapons feel very satisfying to use. Map design is overall good with my favorite maps being Nuk3town, Combine, Fringe, Outlaw, Skyjacked, Micro, Empire and several more.

Graphics in BO3 could still hold up today, and it is fairly optimized for mid-range players. The soundtrack is also great, from SP, MP and Zombies. Treyarch did a really good job in this department.

Zombies in BO3 is personally my favorite in the COD franchise. I'll just summarize my favorite maps here:
- Shadows of Evil, a great map at launch. A visually appeasing map, and one of the most annoying mini-bosses of all time. And let's not all forget the ending cutscene on last gen...
- Der Eisendrache, one of the greatest Zombies maps of all time. Awesome gameplay, overpowered Wonder Weapons, an intense boss fight and an easter egg cutscene that is very touching. I have actually visited the place of inspiration for Der Eisendrache which is in Werfen, Austria and I truly will never forget that moment.
- Gorod Krovi, just like Der Eisendrache it remains as a top map among the players. Dragons and fire everywhere, another awesome easter egg and what is believed to be the last 'actual' map in the Aether story before Revelations.
- And speaking of Revelations, a map that takes you across memory lane. Returning Wonder Weapons, a dope-looking Pack-a-Punch camo and probably one of the easiest maps in Zombies to go for high rounds.
I think we should all appreciate that Treyarch then dropped Zombies Chronicles which then basically revolutionized CoD and some consider it the best game in the series, including me. Some Gobblegums in BO3 are too OP, but they are quite useful when speedrunning easter eggs or high rounds. 

In here, I wanna talk about the Black Market. The Black Market is terrible, but I can say that BO4's adaptation is now miles better than BO3. All weapons are locked behind Supply Drops, old players will know about Triple Plays and how weapons could be earned for free. I had put a lot of money into BO3 (~$600) and despite the 'effort' I now have all weapons from the Black Market, and I promised myself not to spend another Dollar on a Supply Drop. I'm not gonna let the Black Market undermine my thoughts of BO3 because at the end of the day, I'm not gonna spend any more money on it.

BO3 is just overall great. It's the most populated CoD on Steam and still is. It has been the longest supported CoD post-launch, mainly lasting for over 2 1/2 years which shows how much people truly play BO3. From my experience with Call of Duty: Black Ops III, you can theoretically expect endless playtime, however for some people that move on to different games can expect 500+ hours assuming that you are playing MP and ZM only. Definitely worth my purchase with over 2,000 hours on BO3.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Call of Duty: Black Ops 4 review: Guess I'll have to do my review here...
Being Prestige Master in MP and ZM, this is a game that I have enjoyed despite some people's negative thoughts. I am now fully adapted to the MP and as a proud owner of Dark Matter on all modes, it definitely is one of my main achievements in my gaming career. Customization is now better than BO3 with awesome looking animated camos, outfits and weapon variants. But where do you get most of these?

The Black Market! I suppose you didn't need to guess if you read my review of BO3. 
But as I said in it, this Black Market is significantly better after November 12, 2019. This day marks the fact that Activision is making change to their monetization for future games. With the recent update to the Black Market, it will now be possible to obtain ALL items by grinding the game. 'All' as in previous items that could only be purchased. I believe this to be a huge win for all of us as I would have continued to keep on spending, and luckily enough I've only spend $250 in a single year (From April to October). I just don't know why this was implemented long before when Reserve Crates were introduced. But yeah, another year of grinding to completion.

Blackout is indeed fun to play. My favorite limited time modes are Ambush, Alcatraz Portal and Hot Pursuit and Heavy Metal Heroes. I really enjoy stalking up to people and knifing them with the Bowie Knife! Never gets old... My only minor issue was that Blackout seemed to be getting more content than MP and ZM. I understand that Blackout is the pinnacle of BO4, however there has to be an equal amount of content added to all modes. 

Speaking of modes, Zombies has somewhat changed from BO3. Some people say it is significantly harder than the previous game and I agree to a certain extent. The health system is weird and annoys me every time I go down. I am very glad that they added camo progression as soon even though it should have been on launch. And again, I got Dark Matter in Zombies since July 2019. Here's my verdict on my favorite Zombies maps in BO4:
- Blood of the Dead, the remaster (or should I say re-imagine) of the fan-favorite Mob of the Dead. This is my most played map because it's very easy to set up and of course I know the map like the back of my palm. For some players, looking back at it now it seems to be a little bit disappointing on what was done, but I digress
- IX, one of the most immersive maps I've played. Cheers everywhere, tigers in Rome and gladiators constantly coming for you. IX has a very simple map design and good graphics.
- Classified, another reimagined map from "Five". My personal favorite map cuz it's another map that doesn't take long to set up and an easy camping spot.
- Ancient Evil, a visually pleasing piece of art. Excellent gameplay and plenty of space to train zombies. Also the map takes place in Greece FTW ;)
- Tag Der Toten, the last map in CoD Zombies as we say goodbye to our beloved characters. This may be a reimagining of Call of the Dead, but I feel that it looks/plays different to be its own unique map.

I'm kinda sad that Treyarch confirmed that Operation Dark Divide will be their last major content drop in BO4 as they have moved onto their next Call of Duty game in 2020 (or 2021), but nonetheless they will continue supporting BO4 with playlist changes and Double XP. Back in March 2018 Treyarch said that BO4 was supposed to last for years but promises do eventually break. I'll be taking a momentary break from BO4 as I've got no other choice than do delete it as it takes up too much space, and I find myself not coming to this game as often.

I'm only reviewing the Zombies portion of the game as I have no interest in the rest.
The way they took out the fun and replaced it with tedium is disgusting. Who the f**k wants to go through 30 convoluted, needlessly tricky and completely unexplained steps just to last a regular amount of time? I just want to turn on the power, get perks, get guns, pack a punch the guns. I don't want to be forced into a giant, pointless easter egg in every single map just to do the simplest things. It's absolutely insane that they thought anyone would want the game centered entirely around easter eggs when they were only ever simply a novelty that some people liked doing sometimes. Now, EVERYONE is FORCED to do at least some of their garbage, unintuitive steps in every game. This is clearly because they inserted too many overpowered perks and weapons that they needed to make the game actually hard again. 
Not even gonna mention the cheap Gobblegum garbage they injected to rake in extra money from Zombies. 
Overall I regret my purchase and I strongly suggest everyone steer away from this piece of hot trash. As far as I'm concerned, Zombies ended in BO2, the last fun Zombies game.

It's arguably the best entry in the series on that count, both in terms of official Treyarch releases and the community content available here in the workshop. While the on-disk maps don't have a lot of range in terms of formula (all of the on-disk maps aside from "The Giant" are sprawling quest-based maps), the actual design of these maps is fantastic. Seriously, each one of these maps is brilliant in its own way. Give it a go and see for yourself.

The only fun thing about this game is the zombies, and that's the whole reason I even bought this game. The zombies is actually fun once you know what to do, and the addition of cutsomizing weapons that level up the more you use it, it made me want to play zombies more often.
But, you get whiny-ass people on zombies who either leave the lobby when they see people who don't have the exact same high rank as them, or leave in-game when they keep sucking and going down. Plus, it's already hard enough to find a good lobby as it is. 
Despite me playing on a $1400 custom gaming computer that is very powerful, the frame rate lags occasionally. It turns out the game uses more of the RAM in your computer with a recent update. 
As for multiplayer? I've never been too good at PvP type of games, and the multiplayer maybe too fast paced for some casual players. 
If you want a game that is broken and with people who will ruin it more, this game is for you.

UPDATE:
As it turns out, the game doesn't even launch properly now. I have to run it in a "safe-mode" which reduces the quality of the graphics to an exceptionally annoying image quality. The game won't even start now without safe mode, and I can't get a refund on this game due to me playing more than 2 hours. So, I wasted $60 on a game that not only doesn't run, but just recently dropped the price to half of what I paid originally.

Since Black Ops III is on steam summer sale and I bought it a year ago on sale and made a review, I thought I'd make a rehashed review, since at the time of making my old review, I was a filthy casual. Black Ops III is a possibly one of the most flawed call of duty games of all time, with a shitty micro-transaction system, terrible map-design in multiplayer, horrible campaign, and so much more. But past those flaws is the best modern call of duty game of all time, besides the reboot of modern warfare. Lets climb ur way up from bo3's worst content to it's best

Campaign:
Needless to say it's horrible, the main reason you'd want to play a campaign is it's story, and bo3's story is awful, it has a good premise if you know what's happening, but it's impossible to understand without looking up a guide, and even with it, I was still confused looking into it. To add even more insult, there isn't a branching story like bo2, so there wouldn't be any good reason to revisit the campaign unless you want achievements. The gameplay is questionable, challenges return from bo2 which is great, and there are a lot more to do, but not many people would replay missions to complete challenges unless there is a reward, which bo3 has none of in it's campaign, bo2 at least gave extra customization, such as new weapons and perks if you do the challenges in the campaign, bo3 however doesn't which is just upsetting. The new realistic difficulty is pretty cool, albeit very unfair, like it's suppose to be, as it's harder than veteran, of course they're gonna make it very unfair, although, even after completing a mission on realistic, I didn't feel correctly rewarded, unlike when I completed a mission of bo1 or waw, or even bo2 on veteran. Either way, the campaign is terrible, and you shouldn't buy bo3 if you're looking for an interesting or fun story to play, as is most modern cod games.

Multiplayer:
Now being honest, I don't have too much of a say in the multiplayer side of things, as I don't really play multiplayer that often, but I do play with friends on private matches, so I'll start by discussing how I feel about the gameplay. It's great! The boost jumping feels smoother then advanced warfare, and there is an actual cool down to the boost, unlike advanced warfare, meaning the combat will mostly be boots on the ground whilst the boost jumping can be used as extra movement. However, people who have mastered using the boost jumping would be able to use it to their advantage in combat, which can be quite annoying, but those are usually your prestige master people which I don't believe I encountered often. The class customization is awful, there is a pit full amount of secondaries to choose from and the pick ten system. although great for helping diverage into mid-maxing abilities and weapons, does limit choice, so it's sort of a win-lose situation with it. The worst part about the class customization is most of the weapons are only unlockable through unboxing loot boxes, which i'll get to. Either way, class customization doesn't feel strong, plus some weapons aren't balanced very well, such as the brecci, which is still supremely overpowered even without the jitter mods. The grind in bo3 is absurd, but amazing, there are so many things to go for such as dark matter camo, and level 1000, which is why people are still playing this game to this day. and then there are those damn loot boxes. Lootboxes can be opened for free with cryptokeys and completing challenges like winning 75 matches, you also get free weapon bribes which are nice, but it's an insanely long grind which highly encourages one to spend money, which you shouldn't on a game you already payed 60 dollars or less on sale for. There is a supposed 0.8% chance to get a new weapon from supply drops, which is less odds of getting a ray gun mark II from die rise. This system should've died a long time ago, but unfortunetly it would be on bo3's reputation forever as a stain of this great game. Multiplayer's map design is lack luster, there are very few maps I remember besides maybe exodus, but that's because it's a campers dream. The maps were designed to be for boost jumping and wall running, and since i'm more of a boots on the ground call of duty fan, I have not too much say in this, but I do think most of them are boring. In terms of buying dlc, i wouldn't really buy a dlc for multiplayer specifically, as they only come with 4 maps, and I barely played any of the dlc maps, besides maybe sky jacked, they all seem way more boring compared to bo2's dlc maps, which were way better. Bo2's dlc maps had hazards in the enviournment that would make then engaging and add a new level of awarness to the player, for example the map magma, which woould have lava rising on one level and touching it would result in one's death. Again, this was a huge oversight in the developers and the map designers, so with this, I wouldn't reccommend buying bo3's dlc specifically for multiplayer. In conclusion, don't buy bo3 specifically for multiplayer really, as the only thing noteworthy is the grind for cosmetics and levels, but being honest, it's the best advanced movement call of duty multiplayer out there.

Extras:
I can't dwell to deep into this, as some of them I haven't played very much but here's my take. Treyarch put a lot of effort trying to pack bo3 with so much content on disk/without dlc which I loved, a problem I had with bo2 is that they didn't really have any extra modes, while it didn't discount bo2 that much, it did make it a little bleak even compared to bo1. Starting from the worst of the extras is a mode called nightmares, which is bo3's campaign with zombies and as the title implies, it's the player's nightmares, again I didn't play it that much but after the first couple missions, I found it boring and with barely any plot, so in my eyes it's not really worth playing. The next one is free run, which is a nice time trial game where you can help improved your ability to use advanced movement, it's a neat side mode The greatest of all of them would have to go to dead ops arcade 2, it returns from bo1 in glorious fashion and is an absloute blast to play, it feels way better than the original, as it has tons more features than it. I would highly recommend playing it at least once. of course these are small side modes wouldn't merit purchesing a whole game, but they're great distractions and they're fun to play once in a while.

Zombies:
This is bo3's masterpiece, what I would purchese a sixty dollar game for just to play. I mentioned before on how I was a casual player when making my first review of bo3, I sort of only gave huge credit to chronicles and custom zombies, but I didn't talk about bo3's original maps which I'll go in order from
Shadows of evil - A true masterpiece, it's pretty new player friendly if they look out for visual cues, but for the most part, hardcore players would find a lot of enjoyment from this map, I truly find it to be one of zombies must play experience, I love the jazz music as a jazz musician myself, it's awesome to hear it in a zombies map with ancient evils lurking around. The theme is absloutely amazing for a zombies map and there is a lot to work with, there is also a lot of unsolved ee begging to be found in soe, which to this day still need to be solved, which truely makes this map a masterpice. My only gripes are the setup process can be quite tedious and the 4 player required ee, which as a solo player, is a disaster. but if you can get over those flaws, you would find a zombies map that many would consider a top 5.
The giant - This was a great launch map, although I should've been on disk as well, shadows was quite complicated and the giant was great for being it's opposite as a simple recognizable remaster. Despite the fact it was paid, it made a great launch date map to cover for any foils soe might've had with how complex it was. Plus treyarch being the absloute gods add some extra ees

This game has an amazing multiplayer, and zombies. The campaign was not that good but the multiplayer and zombies are truly perfect, I would recommend this game to everyone because of just how much fun I have been having while playing.
Solid game, too scary. This game is scary and I don't like it. 5/5

[u][b]The good:[/b][/u]
1. Campaign Story. 
Even though it strays a lot from what the series has done in the past, the story is really well written and deep. It grips the player right from the start and the way it comes together, piece by piece towards the big revelation, it just works.
2. Gameplay
Lots of new additions here. The gunplay is great as expected from Treyarch but the other things is what makes BO3, the specialist abilities, the skill trees and the freedom to use it however you see fit.
3. Co-Op.
Not gonna say much about this, It's like l4d2 fun but in black ops. Working together your abilities is just next level fun. Treyarch really gave this all a thought before making the game unlike Bo4.

Multiplayer.
Boots on the ground with futuristic gunplay. It just works. At the end of the day, it feels like Call of Duty, (in a good way).

Zombies
Pretty much the reason to buy this game, if you haven't already. "One game to rule them all";  "This one is here to stay"; "GOAT". -- These are the phrases that come to mind when describing this. With custom maps, and a community that has delivered, this is the best zombies experience. Having played the entirety of COD Zombies and having over 2k hours on them combined, I can confidently say that this is the best COD Zombies till date.

Just talking about Bo4 maps. The maps are well thought of and aren't remakes of the old maps (well, technically, Der riese is remade but it's so good that it makes up for the fact that it's remade and even then that's just 1/5. The 4 maps which are new are amazing. So detailed and each with an easter egg and map design that is top tier. Out of all zombies maps, these 4 straight up make the top 10 list. Add Zombies chronicles and custom maps to the mix and you have an unending zombies marathon weekend.

Call of Duty: Black Ops 3 offers a lot of content for the price. The most notible things being the multiplayer, singleplayer, and the zombies. The single player is very weird. It is decently enjoyable even though I have no idea what is even happening in the story anymore. It might not be the best story. It might not be even good, but the solid gameplay makes up for it, and makes the campaign at the very least bearable. The multiplayer I will skip in this review as I am very inexperienced in it. The few times I have played, it was very easy to recognise the potential for fun, but I never really got into it. The zombies is probably the main reason why most people would buy this game nowadays, and it doesn't dissapoint. The zombies is very fun. The progression is awesome, and opens up for customizing weapon kits. The mod support is also very well implemented, and gives nearly infinite amounts of replayability to the game. Now one of the most underrated features... The paintshop. This is the perfect way to personalize your weapons. I wish every game did this. It is so much fun to make skins, and opens up for endless amounts of opportunity, and creativity in making skins, and emblems. The way you make them is intuitive, and never too complicated, but still has enough to make complicated skins. The graphics in this game are really good, and hold up very well. one thing I don't like is that if you have a complicated paint job on your weapon, sometimes the game doesn't display all the layers, and makes your gun look like a half completed skin which is kind of dissapointing. There are also a few extra game modes which are just icing on the cake. Overall I definitely recommend this game.

Call of Duty: Black Ops III is a great game! 
The thing that makes it so great is obviously the Zombie-mode and its many maps. 
If you buy it from Steam you also get the Chronicles edition with it wich lets u play older but reworked maps from mostly Black Ops and World at War. 
You get the most out of it playing with friends but if you don't have friends you could just go into public and find people who also don't have anyone to play with.
You do also get the Zombies map Origins from Black Ops II wich is to many people one of the best Zombies maps in Zombie history. 
One more thing is that the Easter Eggs are so good in this game. I can't speak for every map because i don't have every single one but it's very fun and gives a tough challenge.
The maps you get are as following:
------------------------------------
World at War:
Nacht der Untoten
Verruckt
Shi no Numa
--------------
Black Ops:
Kino der Toten
Ascension
Shangri La
Moon
-------------
Black Ops II:
Origins
--------
If I would summarize the game I would say that if you love Zombies you should get this. But if you are in for Multiplayer just don't buy it because the servers are very bad and there isn't so many players aswell.
Some downsides with the game is that without a sale the game costs 60 dollars and on a sale the game is 30 dollars. the game would be bought more if they would make the game like 40 dollars normally and 20 dollars on sale. Also the DLCs are also very expensive, around 8 bucks per map. But if you have some spare money on your steam account you should definitely buy them. 
The cost of the things wouldn't be a big problem if the game where new, but the game came out 2015 so it is around 5 years old. 
But if we only focus on the Zombies mode its already worth 20-30 dollars. The Campain is boring and not so much to talk about. The multiplayer is fun if it works, but it dosen't.
The graphics isn't so bad either but is definently outplayed by Black ops IIII. But come on, it's from 2015.
Summary:
Buy the game if u have spare coins and do not buy the game if you don't have enough money or if you're just in for the Multiplayer nor the Campain....    Because it's really bad.

BO3 has potentially the worst Campaign of all the COD games, but what it lacks in story mode it more than makes up for everywhere else. The multiplayer for BO3 isn't the typical boots on the ground gameplay, but still manages to be incredible fun. Most guns in this game are memorable, fun and viable, with gameplay that feels smooth and flowing. There are several multiplayer maps that I would deem top quality for COD maps, and most are at the very least memorable. Most of all, this game has a fantastic zombies mode. I think that with it's 5 original maps, as well as the addition of zombies chronicles and the Giant remasters, it is easily the best zombies experience. The engine is the best feeling for zombies and it just amounts to countless hours of fun. 4 out of 5 of the original maps it contributes to the series are fantastic, and I would even say Der Eisendrache is potentially the greatest zombies map of them all. Overall a fantastic game 10/10.

Campaign: Terrible. I played the campaign in its entirety when this game came out 5 years ago. An admittedly cool premise gets gunned down by a confusing, muddled and overall pointless story. Completely skip it.

Multiplayer: ...eh. Apart from the advanced movement plaguing the multiplayer, its fairly standard Call of Duty fare. You might have a better time with it if you like advanced movement.

Zombies: The best. This is the best part about this game bar none. The workshop is almost entirely dedicated to custom zombie maps, guns, powerups, gameplay changes... anything you can think of, this game and the workshop probably has. Its a zombie players wet dream and its done to damn near perfection and is the primary reason why i picked up the game on pc, and is why im giving this a recommended review.

Apart from that, the game has some type of parkour speedrun minigame where you use the advanced movement to run on walls and sometimes shoot targets and get to the end as fast as you can. This was one of the minigames you could play if you were installing this game for the first time on a ps4 or xbox one, but doesnt really serve much of a point on PC, and even on console you would never pick it up again after the game fully installs.

theres also a mini campaign that has zombies. it basically just takes levels from the campaign and adds a totally different story to it. Its... eh. If you play through it, youll probably forget the story within seconds.

TLDR, Campaigns utter ass, multiplayer is eh, and the zombies? Oh yeah, doesn't get much better than this.

Edit: Oh, microtransactions are n this game too. Fuck microtransactions

If you buy the Zombies Chronicles Edition, you're getting SOE, [b]ONE OF THE BEST MAPS OF ALL TIME [/b], and some of the best maps from WaW, BO1 and BO2, including Kino Der Toten, the classic, f****** Origins, [b] ANOTHER CONTENDER FOR ONE OF THE BEST MAPS OF ALL TIME [/b], and a lot more (like Nacht, Ascension, etc.)
If this isn't enough for you, you can buy the Deluxe edition which includes DE and GK, again, two of the few best maps ever and ZNS, which is also pretty good. It also comes with Revelations, but this one isn't as good as the other 3.

FINAL REVIEW:

Here I am in 2020 writing a review for Black Ops III. I bought the Xbox version of this game back when it released and spent my entire senior year of high school getting my cheeks clapped in multiplayer. I ranked up all the way through master prestige before I realized that this multiplayer was buns and that I hated specialists in Call Of Duty games. I would do many things to get that 14 days of my life back. 

Enter the present day, and here I am as a college student. I am displeased with the poor execution of Infinity Ward's Modern Warfare, and I am insulted by 343's existence as a whole. I long for the days of Halo 3/Reach custom games, or maybe for the classic Call Of Duty ground war lobbies full of children screaming racial slurs. Or hell, even a good ol' fashion game of zombies on Der Reise would be enough for me to relieve my adolescent years. You know what would be even cooler? Zombies - in Bikini Bottom. Or Zombies - but in Andy's room from Toy Story. 

To be quite honest, every aspect of the steam version of this game is 100% useless outside of zombies. Multiplayer isn't the most populated thing in the world, and honestly who has paid attention to  a COD campaign after Modern Warfare 3? Yes, the game is listed at FULL PRICE. Its Activision. It's Call Of Duty. Don't act like you're surprised - because unless you have been living under a rock for the last 10 years you shouldn't be. 

If you can get over that pesky price tag, what you will receive is a zombies experience that brings back some of the creative elements that made Zombies great in the first place. This is accomplished through Steam's workshop full of custom made maps that are downloadable for free. Getting a map is as easy as clicking the BIG GREEN BUTTON THAT SAYS SUBSCRIBE and then launching the game after it's finished downloading. 

What is really great about this is that there are countless maps to choose from. The people that design these are so incredibly good at what they do. You can tell that these people actually have a passion for zombies and want to provide players with something fun to play, just like zombies used to be before introducing 423157896 sub plots and stories to the mode. I've downloaded a handful of maps, such as Bikini Bottom Zombies, and Backlot (COD4 map) zombies. There are even Easter eggs that allow you to leave some of these custom maps. Many of them come with objectives that play out just like any other Treyarch zombie map would. The amount of effort that was put into some of these custom zombies maps is absolutely incredible. Lighting, perk placement, sounds, hitmarkers, prices, pack a punch - literally crafted to (sometimes) perfection. It's like the workshop brings you back to World At War and Black Ops 1 era zombies and lets you have fun again. With a group of friends this is 100% a blast. Just imagine you and your homies fighting zombies in a friggan' toilet stall - just awesome!

 I understand that the game is 4 years old and is still full price and yes I think this is stupid too - but look at the opportunities for fun here. You are given the chance to explore so many different maps and modes that you have not played before, while at the same time revisiting some of your finest memories of Call Of Duty zombies. If you are looking for something to take you back to that "golden age" of zombies or just gaming in general I would honestly suggest that you and a couple of your buddies give this a shot. It brought a smile to my face, and it also made me realize how the COD series would benefit from a "Forge" mode of some sort - we can dream right?

In cod standards, BO3 is hella old and that's okay... if you like the zombies mode. BO3 is still by far the best way to experience cod zombies. Unfortunately, buying the game and all dlc's is expensive. But if you're willing to give Activision your money then you will witness cod zombies at it's current highest point. BO3 zombies offers the player the most consistent dlc cycle out of any of the cod games. Each map is unique and just a blast to play. And then.... there's chronicles which remastered some great classics. And lastly, you have a great community of custom map creators who add on another level to this great mode. BO3 is one of my top 10 games of all time thanks entirely to the zombies mode. 10/10

I really only play the Zombies mode. Everything in zombies is so cool to me. The transition of the level counter looks so cool, the power ups are great and so many perks to choose from. The maps, especially the remastered ones are amazing and great to play. Everything about how the arcade style pulls you in. Knowing you can't win, but the rounds are rather fast and fun. Maybe except the first few rounds where the zombies are REALLY slow and take their time to get to you. All rounds about 33+ get rather hard with the amount of zombies coming at you at once. My only complaint is how the remastered maps don't have the WaW (WWII) weapons on the walls. You can obtain a few of them in the mystery box, like the MP40 or STG44. I also like the progression system added, such as leveling weapons and your overall rank for the different campaigns, such as: Campaign, Multiplayer and Zombies. Weapon camos unlocked in the multiplayer black market can be used on the weapons in Zombies, so that's actually pretty cool. The perks being sodas, and having the machines all over the maps are a neat idea.

Why do you think the devs left out singleplayer in 4? It's no good here. While Treyarch didn't do too bad by making it co-op and adding some neat gimmicks, this game isn't for the singleplayer campaign. Black Ops 3 was a bit of a saving grace for the series at the time, because it brought an excellent zombies mode as well as a 7/10 multiplayer. Sure there is still boosters/jetpacks and things like that, but this multiplayer is straight forward and quite balanced. Zombies is even better, I would even say close to the best iteration of it in COD. Right off the bat, with ZC you will get 8 maps, one new map that is the default, but also 7 maps from previous zombies, including Kino Der Toten, Ascension, Nacht der Untoten, etc. Plenty of great maps and modding support is present in this game. 

Overall, zombies will provide great replay value while the multiplayer is a fairly standard and fun distraction to progress and grind in. 7/10

First, the campaign story made no sense to me, but after playing it multiple times, it makes even less sense to me. 

During the campaign, You're chasing the head of the coalescence and designer of Corvus: Krueger. Oh and also Dr. Salim, because he did some wrong things while under gunpoint and together, they are responsible for all the deaths at the Singapore disaster. Why are they responsible? you tell me. Krueger clearly explains that Corvus was a programming bug in the DNI and turned sentient or something and dr. Salim's did what he did to the test subjects, because he was being threatened.

Which brings me to the next point... What the hell is up with DNI? Everybody knows this corvus bug is inside the DNI, which causes 100% probability of death, but still Taylor insists I get the DNI in my brain. Why?? Just because i should have been dead from the robots in the first mission anyway? Hendricks even lays besides me volunteering to get this chip in his head for no reason at all... Hello?? it causes you to die!

But what makes least sense of all, is how at the end, it turned out I was Taylor all along - but didnt realize, because DNI already hacked my brain. Seriously? What are you on about? Taylor was the one who adviced me to get the DNI installed. How was Taylor the one who saved me from the robots in the first mission? I didnt even have DNI during that mission yet.

Call of Duty: Acid Trip is a game truly unlike any other. Some games have "WTF" moments, where you're not sure why something happened or why the story took the turn it did. Black Ops 3 goes above and beyond. It is a "WTF" game, in which you will spend as much time shooting things as you will trying to figure out what the hell is going on. You're on acid. The game world is on acid and so is your character, and between all of this, you'll manage to get your shit together just enough for your FPS gamer instincts to kick in and shoot your way through the hostiles on each level. But it's a challenge. I spent more time frowning while playing the campaign than showing any other expression as my lore-obsessed mind struggled to put together the pieces of how we got from Black Ops 2 (which canonically precedes this) to this chaotic ball of madness.

You start by being thrown into what seems to be a war-torn Earth. The world's population has gone down. Way down. This much is evident from the scenes of carnage and debris all over the place. World War 3 came and went at some point. How else could the environment be explained? There's probably a back story here somewhere, but it's no easier to find than the sanity of the characters, which, due to events in the game that I won't spoil, steadily declines, and your character is no exception.

Yes, there is a story here, and you technically can follow along. That's not the hard part. The hard part is grasping why the hell any of this is happening in the first place. It makes you wonder what kind of drugs the story writers were on. Potent stuff, to be sure. It's a total fever dream every step of the way. Normally, the sheer number of non-sequiturs in a story would automatically mark it as bad, but Black Ops 3 manages to avoid this by dragging you along on a massively immersive experience where you and your character can't tell what's real and what's just going on inside someone's head. In the end, it doesn't really matter. The levels are varied and interesting, and you'll need to use a variety of tactics to make it through in one piece. Hell, there are even boss fights.

From a gameplay standpoint, there isn't much to complain about, leaving your mind to focus on trying to understand the big picture. Perhaps "trying" is too generous. Struggling perhaps, flopping around like a fish out of water as you explore a world where nothing seems to be happening for any logical reason, and rational thought has been replaced with raw instinct and crippling mental insanity trying to work together inside each character's head, including that of the main villain. This meshes pretty well with what you'll be going through as a player, so somehow it all works out, adding to the immersion of the game.

In conclusion, I highly recommend playing this game. There's nothing else quite like it, and the closest thing I can compare it to is if an ordinary first-person shooter and the movie Inception had a baby, and you have been thrust into that baby's head while it does acid, overdoses on nitrous oxide, and probably does half a dozen other drugs that I haven't even heard of. Play it. Enjoy it. Constantly ask yourself what the writers were thinking as the story devolves into a psychotic episode, then shrug as you realize that at the end of the day, what really matters is a good shooting experience. And Black Ops 3 delivers.

Zombies 10/10 - One of the greatest zombies experiences out there. Not only does this game have some of the best base DLC maps ever seen in zombies (Gorod, Shadows, and DE), which are already amazing, but the game went the extra mile to add in ZC. Now that the greatest maps of WaW, Black Ops, and Origins are remastered in their best virions yet. The game goes a step further and adds in modding? Multiplayer 6/10 - I'm not a multiplayer guy, the loot boxes and lack of interesting maps have made this mode even more off-putting for me. I don't care to unlock skins unless it's for zombies, but even then the jet boost feels off and not right for this game style. It's more of a gimic than the other CoD Exo suits, but I still feel games like Titanfall did it way better. Don't buy this game for the multiplayer, just go buy MW2019 on Battlenet if that's what you're looking for.

Alright, so I played this game on both Console and PC. Personally a PC player myself, but going to Console to play was a bit better in terms of playerbase and matches. So, to start, the campaign wasn't awful, but it certainly wasn't good either. You could REALLY tell that it was not crafted to be a good experience, and was not made to be a "play it over again to relive" type of campaign, like other CoD's have been in the past. Moving to multiplayer, since Campaign just makes me cringe talking about it, was really solid at launch. Most of the weapons were decently balanced, maps were pretty good and fit the advanced movement of the game, but I personally don't like the specialist system too much. Maps were crafted to fit both the advanced movement AND Botg gameplay, which is fantastic. After the DLC weapons released, balance started to decline due to DLC weapons being absolutely overpowered compared to the Stock weapons, and I guess this was a move on both Treyarch's and Activision's part. It has gotten better balance-wise, but it's still pretty bad. Supply drop system was and still is a cash grab system. Yeah, spend some of your in game currency to roll loot boxes, and HOPE to get something really good, or just spend money on them because getting Cryptokeys is a bit slow. Constantly rolling duplicates plagues this system, at least WW2 got it right in that department. Sort of. I did really like how they would add a new gamemode for people to try out, and it would eventually stick, thank you devs. Now, onto the Zombies. Most of this will be personal opinions and gripes, which are not representative of what others think of it. I also want to point out that I have only played SOE, DE, and all of the Zombies Chronicles maps. I also want to point out, that I don't use Gums due to the fact that I'm more adapt to the original experience, if you catch my drift. SOE, I felt like it was really "veteran zombie player" heavy, with emphasis on completing the EE and going for high rounds, and the layout was very weird to get used to. The characters didn't really have any, well, character to them. They felt bland. Dumb boss rounds and very annoying dog-type rounds with the flying bugs was a turn off for me personally. Since I haven't really played much of DE, I want to personally say that the layout is okay, and I liked the return of the "original" crew. Zombie Chronicles, is the most I have ever played zombies. Reliving these maps in a better engine is just fantastic. A few gripes though. I really did wish they added some of the classic weapons onto those maps, since the BO3 ones after playing through all of the DLC was just "Yay, another weapon that I have already used for the number'th time". Playing Nacht again on a better looking engine was just a dream come true. I will say, Gums makes this map wayyyy easier than it truly is. The double PaP system is very handy, but I feel like some of them are just gimmicks to make it seem like they are doping something, and some make the game downright easy, Turned and Dead Wire for example. Now, the meat and potatoes, the mod support. THANK YOU TREYARCH FOR FINALLY BRINGING THIS BACK! This has been an absolute godsend, and is probably the only reason I got this game on PC in the first place! Custom maps, custom player models, you name it, they probably have it. With all of the mods that are on the workshop, you will NEVER get bored, especially Zombies players. But yeah, that's my review, I have the comments open if you guys want to drop your own opinions on my review, or if you have something that I missed. Thank you Treyarch!

Look, if you are here for anything other than zombies and all the custom maps, just go elsewhere. Played a single match of multiplayer, top fragged with default loadout and still despised it as A) It's too unfamiliar with all the movement craziness for a COD boomer like me. B) Unsatisfying guns. The future setting doesn't lend itself to raw, and powerful mechanical feeling guns like a Deagle or AK from COD4. Most guns end up feeling like rapid fire pea shooters. Campaign's first mission is hot garbage and had to end it there but I guess it is something. 

The gold is the nostalgia that zombies brings to the table for people that grew up on it and the great community mods and maps that are available to play for free. There are some seriously talented mappers with some rivalling Treyarch's quality. As a result I will cautiously recommend for this reason alone when on sale only.

TLDR; If you dislike zombies this game isn't for you.

Considering I've played when the game was out in 2015, 
It was one of the first I ever got into from the beginning. 
Multiplayer was fascinating using the equivalent to exo suits to jump, and wallrun.
Interesting concepts that felt appealing and sped up the game pace.
The Zombie story line continues into towards its finale of the Aether Saga, with new perks and wonder weapons. 

I genuinely enjoyed the remastered maps for the DLC.

However, in current year, 2020, the lobbies are barren and dead, it takes a hot minute to find a match,
in addition, if you liked any other mode, too bad.
No one else is playing anything other than team deathmatch.

Zombies on the other hand holds up somewhat, people only playing Origins, Kino, and Der Eisendreche.

The game from my perspective was underrated, I think its a solid 8.5/10 experience and worth.
However, due to time passing, it's more of like a 3/10 for prominent hackers, bad connectivity, and overall dead lobbies.

I will solely recommend this game to friends so I can simply have fun with a big lobby like we used to.
If we had more people in here, the game is worth.

Just a heads up, never pay full price, wait until its as low as $45 ish during a sale for the whole game, and all its DLC.
